text:
You could have a look at some of the algorithms used by GraphViz. They seem to have a lot of their algorithms documented here: <https://graphviz.org/theory/>
Some look quite adaptable based on what you want to optimize for: e.g. this seems to be a classic approach (where vertices have repulsion forces applied to them) <https://reingold.co/force-directed.pdf>, adapted here with attractive forces for grouping similar items: <https://watermark.silverchair.com/170853.pdf?token=AQECAHi208BE49Ooan9kkhW_Ercy7Dm3ZL_9Cf3qfKAc485ysgAAArswggK3BgkqhkiG9w0BBwagggKoMIICpAIBADCCAp0GCSqGSIb3DQEHATAeBglghkgBZQMEAS4wEQQMXPtAH97l_F-zFar-AgEQgIICbs7tpUGvgimQdG0xZE3p08lLt-BiOxxlZS8cmA0m4M8d51Nbuizrk5Cry1yGdtk_N4RG8BjfP-zT-sMKIKND9drj-brLrEL07UMdxazkC17tlw_W4hHUhEqb0maiHnkqSHdOAkRWVDRifcu4IdvghBYh7Gww8IUe5PZqwCdc8p0pdWpUAsrpNOW7pT5Ikb0dIQniwoMs01YwUrIVLbq7Kg1ikBQRpiZM8YL425dLuQ-ngMsZDs62yNNZgHKIFda8QDMoCUaOUAOvv_llCv65fuJerBBD_ivuB5_dkE2pfSecqpJOIa0LSFpfWjaiCp51kJbG-xqt3d73IovYARK9YE1bvyjArAzG3JRe_P3AKPfR5ImXc0BZUCFBCH-ygMQ5vS7Wc1S4aZDYqaahz1rhweVlmD4HUsFT1Yc_leWL56d7Avv7knGDcBldvHKPZW5RjcmC1JXB-nEwC8c77PxeDaEtr8g7HR7Wa2ziAJEnpYMVaJ8f7aMWomMpR18pZ9wytwZXpzHr68ynU_9d7hRbMk87fnRVU5z8zuM6W57pB2wa_flk8ibhS-G3M6WjTTVO5vJ6MsENYUbAd6gKV5CxGcW5roIeBYuGQVu8fC0EkmOdt5Dr372UNEmVors_w5FWFqRlbLTY9T4Fz_7g6Yjl09eAoDOG-1wwKLfyJptPZl7JnBlu862iyv2dd1YLcvqzQUYNy68wWd5cCRTqhh1gyWbO0DlUKyhsE71wQyuacwuvgTH7Xqn9-xw4QGRj6vfQbbjjo3Yo84mwHYVnJxOba-siUVK56hNDguWSwEx-g7GAC0T1tFQQWxAPSNfgf4U|https://watermark.silverchair.com/170853.pdf?token=AQECAHi208BE49Ooan9kkhW_Ercy7Dm3ZL_9Cf[…]o84mwHYVnJxOba-siUVK56hNDguWSwEx-g7GAC0T1tFQQWxAPSNfgf4U>

elements.text: You could have a look at some of the algorithms used by GraphViz. They seem to have a lot of their algorithms documented here:
Some look quite adaptable based on what you want to optimize for: e.g. this seems to be a classic approach (where vertices have repulsion forces applied to them)
, adapted here with attractive forces for grouping similar items:
if you're unfamiliar, GraphViz have a few different styles of presentation:
“hierarchical” or layered drawings of directed graphs. This is the default tool to use if edges have directionality.

“spring model” layouts. This is the default tool to use if the graph is not too large (about 100 nodes) and you don't know anything else about it. Neato attempts to minimize a global energy function, which is equivalent to statistical multi-dimensional scaling.
“spring model” layouts similar to those of neato, but does this by reducing forces rather than working with energy.
multiscale version of fdp for the layout of large graphs.
radial layouts, after Graham Wills 97. Nodes are placed on concentric circles depending their distance from a given root node.
circular layout, after Six and Tollis 99, Kauffman and Wiese 02. This is suitable for certain diagrams of multiple cyclic structures, such as certain telecommunications networks.

text: Yes I think it's the "company" that throws me off. I think "should I be using that chanell to talk about my current employer?", I think the more literary "present company" is not a widely used term, so a little confusing
